channel.title: Posts on neither nor

item.title: Shiny app: Interprovincial mobility of journeypersons in Canada
item.description: I made this interactive visualization tool based on Shiny. It presents the data (Statistics Canada Table 37-10-0204-01) in a nice Chord diagram. Please not that this is not an official product from StatCan. English version La version française All programs are available on this GitHub repository.

item.title: Canadian Apprenticeship Registrations and Certifications: Interactive Tool
item.description: This is a Power BI-based data visualization tool I made. Check out at Statistics Canada’s website: English version La version française Many teams at StatCan publish a lot of interesting interative tools, which appear not very well-known.

item.title: Factors associated with the completion of apprenticeship training in Canada
item.description: This article is published on Statistics Canada’s Insights on Canadian Society. The Daily (a short summary of the article for press release): Study: Completing apprenticeship training in Canada Article: Factors associated with the completion of apprenticeship training in Canada Infographic: Completing apprenticeship training in Canada French versions are also available: Le Quotidien, L’article, L’inforgraphie Apprenticeship training is the key pathway for an individual to become a skilled tradesperson in Canada.

item.title: Essays on Family Economics
item.description: This is my doctoral dissertation, which took so much longer time than I planned. The copy is available through Western University library. This thesis studies decisions the family makes regarding household unions, fertility, and child investment. Chapter 2 studies the educational gradient in non-marital fertility and posits that cohabitation is a driver behind the gradient. I build a lifecycle model of fertility and household union choices, featuring a trade-off between quality and quantity of children.

item.title: My Name
item.description: My name is Hyeongsuk Jin. Hyeongsuk is my given name, and Jin is my family name. It’s a Korean name and is written as 진형석1 in Korean characters. I know that many people who don’t speak Korean find my first name - Hyeongsuk - hard to read.2 It’s a name with two syllables - in the way syllables are counted in the Korean language, ‘Hyeong 형’ and ‘suk 석’. The first syllable, ‘Hyeong,’ sounds similar to the English word ‘young,’ but with the sound of ‘h’ in front of it, or a strong initial sound.

item.title: Usual Disclaimer
item.description: All contents in this blog are my own, and none of them are reviewed, supported, or endorsed in any manner by my employer(s). Any opinions or ideas expressed in the contents are strictly my own, and they do not represent my employer’s, any groups' or organizations' I belong to.
